segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Welcome to the annual DEFCON convention. This meeting was held in exciting Las Vegas, Nevada from July 9th through the 11th, 1999. This is videotape number 14.
The past couple of years DT has arranged a meet the fed panel for the black hat briefings which take place immediately preceding DEFCON.
And this year we had such a good turnout of feds for both black hat and DEFCON we decided to mingle them into sitting up on our panel interacting with all of us.
I will tell you also I know that at least one or two of them went through quite a struggle in getting this cleared at the highest levels of government to be here with us.
So first I'd like to introduce you to each of them and give a little history. Probably the most interesting candidate we have here on the panel today is agent Jim Christie.

Raise your hands if you've heard of Jim. Jim was the lead agent in the Hanover hacker case. And if you haven't heard of the Hanover hacker case then there are some books back there in the room that you can take a look at.
On my right we have Phil Loringer who is with headquarters office of the Secretary of Defense, Secretary of the Army, Information Systems Command Control Communications and Computers.
And if you put one more word on there I'm going to run out of breath before I say it. Basically Phil is, I believe, the senior most civilian managing information security programs for the Army.
And on the far end is Jeffrey Hunker. Jeffrey Hunker is with the National Security Council and he is the senior most person handling information warfare, information security issues.
So we have a pretty weighty panel up here and I don't mean that as a bad thing. So without further ado what I would like to do is go ahead and open the floor to questions after Jim starts off.
And if he's got just a small presentation I've told him he has ten minutes or less and then we'll throw him off the microphone. So we'll let Jim start with that.

Okay I'm going to start it off. I'm Jim Christie. I'm a criminal investigator with the Air Force Office of Special Investigations and I'm detailed to the Department of Defense. So I can't do anything without a slide show so this was major teeth pulling here.

So basically it's us versus some of you but I think you guys are outnumbered here. So you say you do it for the challenge, the intellectual challenge and you don't do harm and you're just bringing attention to a particular problem. I think that's bullshit.
So if you really wanted a challenge you would have our jobs. You. Okay all you on this side, all us on this side. Your targets if you're on that side, your targets are unlimited.

It's only limited by your imagination where we have to protect everything from you. You don't have to play by the rules. We do. We're limited only by your imagination again. We're limited by Constitution, statutes, treaties, ethics, morality. Absolutely.
Bullshit!
Just ten slides or less okay?
You can attack whatever you want. We have to protect ourselves 24 by 7 by 365. Forget Leap Year. You can stop attacking any time. We still have to protect all the time.

The government, the budgets haven't gone up. So we basically have to do with what we've got. So now we have a whole new mission area to protect these damn things and we're having to cut other things, maybe social programs.

Bottom line is whether it's the government that you hit or whether it's a private company that you hit, it all gets passed on to everybody and you're all going to pay one way or the other. Plus you had a major head start on us because you're smarter than us.

So our seniors didn't grow up with this technology. They don't understand it. So they're just learning about it. So you guys have been out there developing techniques and the technology is exploding and proliferating and we're just recognizing it's a problem and now it's huge.

So we're way, way behind you guys. You guys can align yourself with anybody whether it's acting alone, joining a group, multiple groups, criminal organizations, terrorist organizations, nation states and we have to protect against all of that.

Your motives are all different. We already talked about challenge, that's bullshit. You can just be malicious. You can be the same kid I grew up with that went around shooting BB guns, shooting people's windows and light poles out. The only difference is that now you put national security at risk.

There's all kinds of different reasons that you give, but we still have to protect everything from all those different motives. You don't require major resources. Try protecting everything. We really have a major challenge to protect against everything.

You can be anybody from the ankle biter to that nation state and the problem that we have is that we can't tell the difference until we trace it back to where the little son of a bitch's fingers meet the keyboard.
We have to run every case as if it was a nation state or a terrorist organization. It's not that we target ankle biters. They're probably the only ones we can catch.

We have geographical boundaries. If you think about law enforcement agencies, what we have jurisdiction for, it's always based on geography. A city, a county, a state, a country where cyberspace has no boundaries.

Transcending these boundaries and the rules that go along with those boundaries make things really difficult for us. You could be singularly focused on breaking into a particular system. We have other competing priorities, espionage, murder, terrorism, all these other things, to protect you.
Most of all, protect your rights. In the old days, the challenge was not to get caught. That wasn't much of a challenge. The government is starting to wipe all the start and the twinkle a little bit.

It's going to be a little bit more dangerous for you. You don't want to jeopardize your future employment, your security, and even your freedom. Join the good guys. It's not like we don't need the help.
We've got a major problem coming up with Y2K. Don't kick a cripple.
It just stirs your patriotic feelings, doesn't it?
On that note, let's open the floor for questions.
Can you please stand up and speak up really loudly?

You guys are technologically in the know for some of the state networks. Do you agree with the current litigation that's happening as far as making even an attempt at hacking or breaking into anything illegal?
What exactly was the question?
Do you agree with the current litigation that's attempting to make even the attempt to break into a system illegal and have legal consequences?
Litigation meaning that somebody could sue you? No, litigation is when you sue for civil purposes. You mean legal, like prison.
Can I have plain English here for the crowd?
Can everybody hear me? I'm not familiar with the litigation you're referring to.
I do think it's important that we protect privacy rights for all Americans.
And that is an important part of what makes our nation what we are.
It's an important part also of why there's a number of terrorist groups and there's a number of nations out there that are starting to look at cyber attack as a means of hurting us.
And I'm for everything that's going to protect the rights of Americans to be secure with the information they put into trusted hands.
Whether that's going to be information they share with their employer or information that they share with the government.
And if protecting those rights means making the job of people who are breaking illegally into systems harder, I think that's a good thing to be doing.
As far as the internet goes, is the government preaching that people should take the responsibility for what they put as far as personal information on the internet?
Or is it putting responsibility on the people that are storing personal information on the internet?
That was a very good question.
Basically, in summary, he said, does the government consider personal responsibility when you place information on the internet for securing that information, correct?
Or is the responsibility for the insecure placement of that information in the hands of the groups who are able to exploit the vulnerabilities that are there?
Yeah, like, it's pretty much an open thing. It's pretty much your fault and their fault.
Because you know it came from the internet.
What I would say about that, the analogy I would make is, you shouldn't punish somebody for not locking their house and walking into their house and going through their file cabinet.
That's still, you know, illegal entry.
And violating their rights.
As far as the openness on the internet, do you guys think it's making it a little bit safer for people to not get their information stolen out?
I think part of that is an education problem.
People think the internet's secure.
This is a whole different group.
You guys understand what goes on.
It's a party line.
Whereas most people don't understand that.
They think they're on the telephone.
Guy in the red stood up first.
My question is, with all these hackers here inside the US, compared to other countries in the US alone, is there a lot less risk of getting busted in the US?
Ask the international panel of government experts that will be here next year.
I had a question.
It was kind of the same question at the time when there were hackers.
We were allowed to hack other sites in the facility, like most of the sites in New Saudi Arabia.
So that was sanctioned by the government to do that.
It's such an important issue.
So what's the cost of that?
Are we allowed to do that for political reasons?
Let me take that.
As ethics and morality, as your slides show, greatly increase when hacking increases abroad and other countries, not just in the United States.
Morality at least downgrades feelings for hackers to a point where conditions will be developed that will be solely based on finding and attacking and punishing hackers to the extent of the law.
Let's look at this as two separate issues.

The first issue, which was a very valid question, was what is the difference in endorsing activities against countries that we are actively involved in hostile actions with, versus the government's response to our own citizens conducting such activities.
Was that basically your question?
I'll take a crack at it.
As for the reports about what did or did not take place in Yugoslavia, I can't comment on that.
I don't know.
Can either of our other panelists comment on it?
Mr. Launder?
No comment.
I do defense.
But there is a second part to this, which is there are other nations out there that are actively developing cyber attack capabilities aimed at the U.S.
And you can find in the public record officials in China and Russia.
I know nothing of...
I think what he's saying is that they're building organized cyber war capabilities.
Is that what you're saying?
No.
I'm not aware of any of that.
Jim?
I sure hope we're doing that.
We use cruise missiles.
We should use any technique and tool available to us.
But we used a lot of cruise missiles in Yugoslavia.
But I didn't want you guys to have them and use them when you want them.
Eventually you'll figure out how to build them anyway.
Let me hear.
Let me get a comment in here.
Joe has a comment.
I don't know how well this is working.
Okay, it is.
For years, when your parents were growing up and I was still in high school, we were talking about an arms race.
We were talking about the Cold War, countermeasures and measures.
I submit to you that today we are in an arms race.
The arms race today is a cyber arms race.
It is cheaper and sometimes, I guess you could imagine, more effective to keep a ship from leaving port
because you have filed up the navigation system than it is to let that sucker sail and blow it out of the water.
It is just a new weapon.
We're very concerned that those capabilities that are being developed out there by kiddie scripters and other folks
will eventually be picked up and realized what kind of value they could actually be.
When that value is truly realized, we're not talking about replacing somebody's webpage.
We're talking about killing folks.
And that we remain very concerned about.
Yes, we are in an arms race and it is on today.
In the back.
I'm going to put this in there.
I was distracted for a second as I was handing the...
More money.
Yes, more money.
There is more money.
There's a lot of money.
There's more money.
There's three major new threats that have emerged over the last eight years for Americans.
There's chemical and biological weapons and you've heard about the concerns about anthrax.
There's the concerns about using radioactive and radiological weapons.
And thirdly, there's a concern about cyber attack.
I deal with cyber attack.
It's a real threat.
There are real nasty people out there who are developing capabilities aimed at the U.S.
And the federal government has dramatically increased the amount of funding.
By how much?
By about 40%.
How much is that?
That's a billion.
It'll be a billion and a half this next year.
We expect quite a considerable amount going forward.
A lot of that's going to be in R&D.
A lot of that is going to be in training and education.
Frankly, for some of the people out here, for information security.
Nod your head yes.
I think Phil wants to address that.
Let me see if I can address that.
You know, beauty is in the eye of the beholder.
You've heard that.
Reaction to an action is also very similar in this extent.
You've had a couple lawyers talk to you guys today, talking to you.
In essence, they may not have said it, but they were talking about the development of case law.
Many of the things that are going on today for prosecution and so forth, no one's ever done it before.
Not sure what the countermeasure to the measure ought to be, as I mentioned.
But if you think about some of our other countries on this planet,
the way they counter hackers, I'll bring you back to a story not too long ago from China.
Two hackers busted into a national Chinese bank, ripped off $37,000.
They were caught.
You know what their punishment was?
They were shot.
I'm telling you, that's perhaps so.
Do we do that in the United States?
And the answer is no.
I don't know of any hacker we're going to go out and shoot.
So are you saying that we're still in the transition period trying to figure out what an accurate punishment is?
I think that it will be a number of years before we have case law that is as standard as burglary crimes are today.
I just have one comment.
How many out here have gone to jail for hacking?
Not a whole lot of you, huh?
They're in the pimp suites.
Do you guys go to jail?
Do you guys go to jail?
No, but I have a question.
Just checking.
Okay.
Okay.
That's more on the small side of the problem than big.
I have to say, I'm a good guy, but not on your side personally.
I think the reason why I can't say I want to voice good guts is because I have seen many friends who don't retire as a career
often go to jail for extended periods of time, generally each year.
Now, nowadays, I don't do anything that would be considered illegal,
certainly at least as far as I know.
I've seen a lot of people do this.
But just a few months ago, I had to track down a very annoying group of security agents
who were being e-traveled to the enclosures.
In the process, I found that e-travelers had basically gained access to a very important government database.
You can see it right here.
If you don't want to read that, you can totally unsubscribe.
I got in contact with the administrator there, and, A, I had to tell him about it.
But, B, I had convinced him not to tell you about it.
And the reason for this is because he was up to a bunch of things.
He was curious, maybe a little clueless,
and would not think of bringing down anything that had to do with the government.
Because the government tends to overreact.
And the point being is, they've been doing it for years.
When all they're doing is just moving around like this.
And while I had to turn around, and I had to deal with it,
what does it mean?
Because I'm discerning, because I know you overreact.
Comments?
Yes, I have two important comments to make about that.
The first is that, as was pointed out before,
with the growth of the internet, with the growth of electronic commerce the way it is,
case law and societal norms about how we treat this is an evolution.
And it's not the government that sets and determines that.
It's going to be a combination of congressional, state action,
and individual decisions by courts and by private plaintiffs in terms of that.
And you have to be part of that process.
We don't set all of that.
We don't make it all up.
It's a process that involves all of us.
And it certainly is a process in evolution.
I don't claim that the current case law and the current laws that we have
for protecting electronic communications, privacy, and information security are perfect.
They've changed. The technology has changed.
And we have to recognize that we're in evolution right now.
So what I would ask is, cut us a break in terms of saying,
you, the government, are doing this.
And recognize the fact that we're in a rapid transition.
The Congress is going to be involved in this.
The state legislatures are going to be involved in this.
And a lot of lawyers and court action are going to be involved.
Second point is, in terms of sharing information with the government,
one of the things we're working very carefully on right now
is to make certain that the sort of case that you're involved in right there,
where you are tracking somebody down and the like,
that we have the mechanisms in place so that you can talk to us
or talk to law enforcement as appropriate
and not face the concerns about overreaction.
It's a big issue. It's an issue we've never faced before.
It raises a number of legal issues,
both in terms of how corporations and lawyers look at it,
as well as in terms of security and how law enforcement looks at it.
But we are working on that very much.
I know it's not the right thing to do,
but I don't want to send him to jail for four years.
In the back with the glasses.
Well, there are several different categories of folks
that didn't violate the law and have the same capability that you have.
The problem is scope.
Like I said in a couple of my slides,
you can target individual systems, you can work when you want.
Our folks have to protect everything, which is a huge problem.
And we have good people out there who have a good set of morals.
And what we need for you guys to do is,
before you get caught, before you cause damage
and ruin potential job security in the future,
is to come to our side.
Because you're going to get those same capabilities,
and you'll probably get better tools.
And you'll find out what the challenge really is.
Money.
Over on the end.
He basically said what part of this process is driven by
getting a federal indictment under their belt.
I'm not a prosecutor, I'm an investigator.
See, if you paid $8.95 in advance,
you could have hurt the Department of Justice guy at Black Hat.
And like I said earlier, when we start an investigation,
we don't know who the bad guy is.
We're not looking for script kiddies.
We're looking for the folks who can cause significant damage.
So now that we run that investigation,
it turns out to be a 21-year-old.
Should we just turn our back?
I don't think so.
The issue is, the question is,
are some of the prosecutions just based off of
somebody trying to simply get an additional prosecution
or indictment under their belt?
I'm going to answer that from the perspective of
the National Security Council at the White House
and the focus that we're putting on cyber security right now.
And I'll speak from that perspective and the funding
and the focus that we're putting on that.
We're concerned about threats to our economic
and our national security that are not individual hackers.
They're not disgruntled insiders.
They're well-organized, well-funded, malicious groups
that are trying to destroy our country.
There are countries and there are terrorist groups.
Are you at liberty to say this?
I mentioned two of them earlier.
You said China and Russia.
Right. I've publicly talked about this.
And there are others.
Stand up.
Stand up.
Scurry Crypto Laws.
Let's go with Jeffrey Hunker on that from the National Security Council.
Because we don't want strong encryption in the hands of terrorists.
The comment slash question made over here was,
don't terrorists already have strong encryption?
Well...
Excuse me.
Okay.
Will the government be ensuring our privacy if we can't do it for ourselves?
Could I have an easier question, please?
Okay. Let him comment.
Strong encryption is available to all Americans.
The public key encryption and the key escrow proposals that have been made
have the sort of legal protections to protect Americans' privacy rights.
Go ahead.
Earlier, you said that groups that are just exposing problems
that are bringing things to the attention of the public
are rationalizing it.
Since then, do you oppose activity such as the law
to uncoerciously cracking or making purchase of a product on their own
to expose deep, deep legal sins against the state of the United States of America?
No, I think that's a great thing.
Absolutely.
You know, as soon as you violate the law by breaking somebody else's privacy,
that's a whole different issue.
To test products, to hone your skills on your own systems or with permission,
that's great.
And that's the kind of people that we want.
You know, when you do that work of systems,
there are a lot of treaties that America,
a number of other countries signed,
the West Coast Treaty of World Independence,
intellectual property, development of the nation,
and it suggests that you should not reverse-engineer something
because that is essentially to see if it's crap or not
because if you want to trust it, you can't test.
Because if you test, you may determine that it's faulty
and it's a circular catch-22 thing.
And I have a question that actually says,
if you're goal is to actually have secure systems that you can trust,
you know that you need to be in the middle,
that these people are smarter than anything else that the world has.
And if your goal is a secure system, which option do you want?
Do you want the systems to be just tested by your own controls
or, you know, a lot of these misconfigurations?
Do you want your own citizens to test them?
If they're not going to screw them up,
if they're not going to,
you're just going to test them and provide perhaps a future possibility
to say, hey, you've got a problem, fix it.
So that was my reason for revising it.
Or do you want foreign people?
If you block your own people,
and that's the candidate,
if you block your own people from telling you you have problems
and you have extremely hard to enforce foreign actual problems,
you're in a cash-flowing position,
you're not going to get your secure systems,
and you need to accept that you've got a secure system.
I'm not...
No.
Let me attempt to summarize this.
It has to do with...
Black kids don't have to reverse engineer without getting in trouble.
Is that what you're saying?
Right.
If you don't let them do it,
you're in worse trouble than any other country in the world.
I'm not an expert in this,
and so I'm just going to speak from a personal capacity.
I think that the language in the WIPO treaty
was not written with the intent of making illegal the sort of reverse engineering that you're talking about,
and we hope to clarify and rectify that issue.
Good.
Thank you.
Also, someone asked me to interject that with PKR e-commerce,
you mentioned the government having an interest in supporting that,
but isn't it a fact that it would only require the injection of a subpoena to...
Just an observation.
The court would be disrequired to issue a subpoena for it to get used,
and not have a judge deal with it
to search a warrant,
a warrant to get a wiretap to it.
I mean, there's a lot of places to get used.
Well, if we need to...
Again, so it goes back to how much is the government really ensuring our privacy for us?
You know, the whole issue of PKI and key recovery is part of an ongoing dialogue,
and if people feel that there needs to be stronger legal protections,
then let's have stronger legal protections.
The Congress is considering it.
The administration is considering it.
It's going to be part of case law.
Let's build them in.
But you're not listening to what I'm talking about.
You know, what are you getting at?
You had a question?
You're saying that there is a dialogue between me and the people concerned by this case,
and I would suggest to you that dialogue seems to be one way.
The government keeps saying,
yes, it does,
and we keep saying,
no, I don't understand how that is a dialogue.
Question in the back.
You want to comment on it?
We have a...
Vote.
We have a Congress.
Congress and Senate.
That will be effective.
You had a question in the back.
Please speak up louder.
Benefits to Kiesco?
I wish the FBI were here.
Does someone have a non-PKI Kiesco e-commerce question?
In the man's shirt.
At what level of legislations are we acting?
Let's have the Army guy answer that.
I'm not really sure I like you.
In fact, if there's anybody from global hell here, I'd like to meet them.
This is an issue where you have a number of backup servers,
and quite frankly, we had an oops.
One of the backup servers wasn't fully backed up properly,
and that Argonne temp file was still there,
and someone exploited that.
It is not a big sin,
but it was because it was very public.
Those kind of things, I'm afraid, will happen on any system that you have.
Assist administrators, if you are one, you know you're overworked.
There isn't enough hours in the day just to maintain continuity of operation in your systems.
And if you look at all the advisories that are out there,
whether they come out of Corning and Mellon,
whether they come out of the Assist,
whether they come out of 101 or other places,
I question whether we will ever have the capability to implement all of them in a secure manner.
I don't think you realize how huge we are.
I mean, seriously.
The problem is education and training.
The system administrators that we have,
their job and their priority is to keep the thing up and running,
and it never has been security.
Now security has become a priority,
and they don't have the training and education to make this thing work.
So it's going to take time, and it's going to take resources,
and the problem that we have in the government is as soon as we train them,
then the private sector buys them.
I would like to get paid more, too.
You see that?
They're in the private sector.
I don't know how many machines we have that are still approved,
and as far as security exists or not.
Do you have a question?
Absolutely agree.
Question?
The issue has to do with product liability for software.
Say it.
You know you want to say it.
It's a good question.
I'm glad you brought it up, and we're looking at it.
I would like nothing more.
Wait, did you say you would like nothing more than?
I would like nothing more than to have some more market incentives out there
to ensure that if products are going to be put out on the market,
that they do what they're supposed to be doing.
When you do that with cars, I think that should be true for information systems as well.
Let me comment on this as well.
I obviously can't talk from the White House because that's not where I work,
but let me tell you what we are looking at from a Department of Defense perspective.
In fact, the Department of the Army is driving this particular initiative.
Everything we buy, we buy a journeyman contract,
so we develop the specification characteristics in the deliverables.
We do that predominantly against COTS because that's what the mandate by Congress has been.
They have reduced our development R&D resources and so forth that we have to go commercial.
However, in those contracts, we are now stating very specifically
that the applications that we buy have to have some sort of guarantee that there is no malicious code,
the buyer is free, and they operate as intended.
Now, the big hammer is if you don't deliver, we don't buy from you again.
He said the word. He said the N-word.
We do buy from Microsoft, but I will tell you that we have increased our cooperation
in the area of security with the Microsoft folks out of Washington.
They have come out with some rather interesting solutions to the problem that you all have brought out in the past DEVCON.
You have 340-1 in your ID. That was over a year ago.
And they still haven't done it. They can't do it.
And you are still buying their software and still putting it in your system.
And we're still defending this country, aren't we?
Okay, question over there on the side.
Loud, please.
Very good comment. Very good question.
The question is, if the concern is lowest price, what is the problem with open source?
That's a really good question.
And we are looking at that very carefully.
That's the White House guy.
I work for the Department of Defense.
When you say that you guys are defending the United States,
there are people in here that I'm sure are veterans that are defending the United States,
but they're not choosing their own businesses to be as stupid as to continue buying from our partners.
So why did the Army continue to buy from our partners?
Who was it?
I'm getting struck down.
Loud, please.
And measures and countermeasures.
Absolutely, as long as you don't test them on somebody else who doesn't know it and doesn't consent to it.
Sure.
That's a very good question.
I really have no comment on that.
It gets into so many issues of legal liability, civil liability for organizations that want to hack back,
take countermeasures, and the like.
I know that it's something that people have been looking at, thinking about, and maybe doing,
but it raises a whole bunch of issues.
Are you just talking about testing your own products in your own environment,
or are you talking about going out and developing tools and techniques on somebody else?
An innocent bystander.
You're doing it in your own environment, though, right?
I don't have a problem with that.
Question?
Loud.
Loud.
Louder.
Does it bother you that without us, you wouldn't be here to document problems and how to fix them
so that some, you know, real malicious group actually could come and attack you?
Phil will comment.
Basically, he said, does it bother you that the people in this room, the people here at DEFCON,
are the ones finding the vulnerabilities?
Would you prefer it be us to find them before somebody else come along and find them and exploit you,
like one of these terrorist groups that you've referred to or intelligence services?
The gut answer at 2 o'clock in the morning, it bothers the hell out of me.
The other answer, though, from an academic perspective,
this is the kind of conferences where this kind of information can be exchanged.
And if you don't think that it is being exchanged, it certainly is.
These are the kind of conferences that you should kind of applaud yourselves
because you're the kind of folks that are actually making the industry more conscious of what the hell they're putting out there.
I'm sorry, I didn't hear that.
Well, if we're only listening to you once a year, we certainly want to have a better track record
so that you can't say that next year.
Your second question?
How much do your jobs pay?
How much do you make now?
You're up now.
He needs to eat 15 hours, everybody. He has the next round.
Okay, you.
John.
Yeah, John.
So, when I go to conferences, I have a choice to actually talk to all of you about what I read.
These are all very small elements of the overall picture of the information you want to get out into the world.
How much do you pay?
So, it's a process of meeting requirements and other requirements to be recommended.
So, now it's like you're analyzing the overall big picture of what's going on.
If I just started on DEFCON, I'm actually not interested in experiencing any private sector
that's going to experience it.
It would be a big loss of time for you guys.
Who's looking at the overall big picture and not just hearing that?
Who's buying that?
Well, that's why Jeffrey's here.

Well, that's my story.

I know you have some honest government contractors.
Who are they?

The point is that the government has a lot of trouble communicating amongst itself as well as with private industry.
And so, what are we doing about making certain that we actually have a full picture?
The President 18 months ago signed a couple of executive orders specifically reorganizing the federal government
so that we do, in fact, for the first time, have in the White House.
My position was created as well as the position of another person in the National Security Council
specifically to coordinate all the work that's taking place across the federal agencies.
We've also created a special unit that for the first time has brought together the FBI and the Secret Service
and the intelligence community.
And it's frankly starting to work very closely with the private sector in terms of exchanging information
about the sort of new threat that we're talking about.
So, can we email you?
Absolutely.
Do you want my address?
Yes.
It's jeffrey.a.hunker at nsc.eop.gov.

For those of you who didn't hear, he made a comment regarding HIPAA, health information privacy protection, protection of medical records and so forth.
Is there now a requirement to have adequate protection in place by 2001? Are there similar legislative activities going on to protect areas outside of health information?

Not yet in terms of mandating it. We'd much prefer to be working on a voluntary basis. If that doesn't work, then maybe somebody will propose it, but that's certainly not something that's on the cards right now.

You mentioned earlier childhood warfare. The one thing that I can say about everybody on this side of the table, without anyone else in the room, is that what now? We all fight every day for more against stupidity.
Every good question is not made intelligently and finally answered. Every time we have a good question, it's either no comment or it's, we're looking into that.
I've never become more and more frustrated with all of the idiots. Everyone's got a great voice. We all seem to know what's going on, and we've all been so wrong in dozens.
But if you want to hire a voice of the same idiot that hasn't been able to figure it out for years, that's why we all go to Texas to build our own companies.
That's a really good question.
Well, I think this has been an interesting Meet the Fed panel. We are down to no time. Is our next speaker here? Are you the next speaker?
Do you think that this was a beneficial addition to the con this year? Then we'll do it again next year and we'll see who shows up.
And also, Philip Moringer will be speaking tomorrow at 10 a.m. He's the Army guy.
